trans-unit.source: An introduction to different ways you can use the Service Bus to connect Azure applications to other software.
trans-unit.target: An introduction to different ways you can use the Service Bus to connect Azure applications to other software.

trans-unit.source: Azure Service Bus
trans-unit.target: Azure Service Bus

trans-unit.source: Whether an application or service runs in the cloud or on premises, it often needs to interact with other applications or services.
trans-unit.target: Whether an application or service runs in the cloud or on premises, it often needs to interact with other applications or services.

trans-unit.source: To provide a broadly useful way to do this, Azure offers Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: To provide a broadly useful way to do this, Azure offers Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: This article takes a look at this technology, describing what it is and why you might want to use it.
trans-unit.target: This article takes a look at this technology, describing what it is and why you might want to use it.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus fundamentals
trans-unit.target: Service Bus fundamentals

trans-unit.source: Different situations call for different styles of communication.
trans-unit.target: Different situations call for different styles of communication.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, letting applications send and receive messages through a simple queue is the best solution.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, letting applications send and receive messages through a simple queue is the best solution.

trans-unit.source: In other situations, an ordinary queue isn't enough; a queue with a publish-and-subscribe mechanism is better.
trans-unit.target: In other situations, an ordinary queue isn't enough; a queue with a publish-and-subscribe mechanism is better.

trans-unit.source: And in some cases, all that's really needed is a connection between applications—queues aren't required.
trans-unit.target: And in some cases, all that's really needed is a connection between applications—queues aren't required.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides all three options, letting your applications interact in several different ways.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides all three options, letting your applications interact in several different ways.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus is a multi-tenant cloud service, which means that the service is shared by multiple users.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus is a multi-tenant cloud service, which means that the service is shared by multiple users.

trans-unit.source: Each user, such as an application developer, creates a *namespace*, then defines the communication mechanisms she needs within that namespace.
trans-unit.target: Each user, such as an application developer, creates a *namespace*, then defines the communication mechanisms she needs within that namespace.

trans-unit.source: Figure 1 shows how this looks.
trans-unit.target: Figure 1 shows how this looks.

trans-unit.source: Figure 1: Service Bus provides a multi-tenant service for connecting applications through the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Figure 1: Service Bus provides a multi-tenant service for connecting applications through the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Within a namespace, you can use one or more instances of four different communication mechanisms, each of which connects applications in a different way.
trans-unit.target: Within a namespace, you can use one or more instances of four different communication mechanisms, each of which connects applications in a different way.

trans-unit.source: The choices are:
trans-unit.target: The choices are:

trans-unit.source: *Queues*, which allow one-directional communication.
trans-unit.target: *Queues*, which allow one-directional communication.

trans-unit.source: Each queue acts as an intermediary (sometimes called a *broker*) that stores sent messages until they are received.
trans-unit.target: Each queue acts as an intermediary (sometimes called a *broker*) that stores sent messages until they are received.

trans-unit.source: Each message is received by a single recipient.
trans-unit.target: Each message is received by a single recipient.

trans-unit.source: *Topics*, which provide one-directional communication using *subscriptions*-a single topic can have multiple subscriptions.
trans-unit.target: *Topics*, which provide one-directional communication using *subscriptions*-a single topic can have multiple subscriptions.

trans-unit.source: Like a queue, a topic acts as a broker, but each subscription can optionally use a filter to receive only messages that match specific criteria.
trans-unit.target: Like a queue, a topic acts as a broker, but each subscription can optionally use a filter to receive only messages that match specific criteria.

trans-unit.source: *Relays*, which provide bi-directional communication.
trans-unit.target: *Relays*, which provide bi-directional communication.

trans-unit.source: Unlike queues and topics, a relay doesn't store in-flight messages-it's not a broker.
trans-unit.target: Unlike queues and topics, a relay doesn't store in-flight messages-it's not a broker.

trans-unit.source: Instead, it just passes them on to the destination application.
trans-unit.target: Instead, it just passes them on to the destination application.

trans-unit.source: *Event Hubs*, which provide event and telemetry ingress to the cloud at massive scale, with low latency and high reliability.
trans-unit.target: *Event Hubs*, which provide event and telemetry ingress to the cloud at massive scale, with low latency and high reliability.

trans-unit.source: When you create a queue, topic, relay, or Event Hub, you give it a name.
trans-unit.target: When you create a queue, topic, relay, or Event Hub, you give it a name.

trans-unit.source: Combined with whatever you called your namespace, this name creates a unique identifier for the object.
trans-unit.target: Combined with whatever you called your namespace, this name creates a unique identifier for the object.

trans-unit.source: Applications can provide this name to Service Bus, then use that queue, topic, relay, or Event Hub to communicate with one another.
trans-unit.target: Applications can provide this name to Service Bus, then use that queue, topic, relay, or Event Hub to communicate with one another.

trans-unit.source: To use any of these objects, Windows applications can use Windows Communication Foundation (WCF).
trans-unit.target: To use any of these objects, Windows applications can use Windows Communication Foundation (WCF).

trans-unit.source: For queues, topics, and Event Hubs Windows applications can also use Service Bus-defined messaging APIs.
trans-unit.target: For queues, topics, and Event Hubs Windows applications can also use Service Bus-defined messaging APIs.

trans-unit.source: To make these objects easier to use from non-Windows applications, Microsoft provides SDKs for Java, Node.js, and other languages.
trans-unit.target: To make these objects easier to use from non-Windows applications, Microsoft provides SDKs for Java, Node.js, and other languages.

trans-unit.source: You can also access queues, topics, and Event Hubs using REST APIs over HTTP.
trans-unit.target: You can also access queues, topics, and Event Hubs using REST APIs over HTTP.

trans-unit.source: It's important to understand that even though Service Bus itself runs in the cloud (that is, in Microsoft's Azure datacenters), applications that use it can run anywhere.
trans-unit.target: It's important to understand that even though Service Bus itself runs in the cloud (that is, in Microsoft's Azure datacenters), applications that use it can run anywhere.

trans-unit.source: You can use Service Bus to connect applications running on Azure, for example, or applications running inside your own datacenter.
trans-unit.target: You can use Service Bus to connect applications running on Azure, for example, or applications running inside your own datacenter.

trans-unit.source: You can also use it to connect an application running on Azure or another cloud platform with an on-premises application or with tablets and phones.
trans-unit.target: You can also use it to connect an application running on Azure or another cloud platform with an on-premises application or with tablets and phones.

trans-unit.source: It's even possible to connect household appliances, sensors, and other devices to a central application or to one other.
trans-unit.target: It's even possible to connect household appliances, sensors, and other devices to a central application or to one other.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus is a generic communication mechanism in the cloud that's accessible from pretty much anywhere.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus is a generic communication mechanism in the cloud that's accessible from pretty much anywhere.

trans-unit.source: How you use it depends on what your applications need to do.
trans-unit.target: How you use it depends on what your applications need to do.

trans-unit.source: Queues
trans-unit.target: Queues

trans-unit.source: Suppose you decide to connect two applications using a Service Bus queue.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you decide to connect two applications using a Service Bus queue.

trans-unit.source: Figure 2 illustrates this situation.
trans-unit.target: Figure 2 illustrates this situation.

trans-unit.source: Figure 2: Service Bus queues provide one-way asynchronous queuing.
trans-unit.target: Figure 2: Service Bus queues provide one-way asynchronous queuing.

trans-unit.source: The process is simple: A sender sends a message to a Service Bus queue, and a receiver picks up that message at some later time.
trans-unit.target: The process is simple: A sender sends a message to a Service Bus queue, and a receiver picks up that message at some later time.

trans-unit.source: A queue can have just a single receiver, as Figure 2 shows, or multiple applications can read from the same queue.
trans-unit.target: A queue can have just a single receiver, as Figure 2 shows, or multiple applications can read from the same queue.

trans-unit.source: In the latter situation, each message is read by just one receiver-for a multi-cast service you should use a topic instead.
trans-unit.target: In the latter situation, each message is read by just one receiver-for a multi-cast service you should use a topic instead.

trans-unit.source: Each message has two parts: a set of properties, each a key/value pair, and a binary message body.
trans-unit.target: Each message has two parts: a set of properties, each a key/value pair, and a binary message body.

trans-unit.source: How they're used depends on what an application is trying to do.
trans-unit.target: How they're used depends on what an application is trying to do.

trans-unit.source: For example, an application sending a message about a recent sale might include the properties *Seller="Ava"* and *Amount=10000*.
trans-unit.target: For example, an application sending a message about a recent sale might include the properties *Seller="Ava"* and *Amount=10000*.

trans-unit.source: The message body might contain a scanned image of the sale's signed contract or, if there isn't one, just remain empty.
trans-unit.target: The message body might contain a scanned image of the sale's signed contract or, if there isn't one, just remain empty.

trans-unit.source: A receiver can read a message from a Service Bus queue in two different ways.
trans-unit.target: A receiver can read a message from a Service Bus queue in two different ways.

trans-unit.source: The first option, called *ReceiveAndDelete*, removes a message from the queue and immediately deletes it.
trans-unit.target: The first option, called *ReceiveAndDelete*, removes a message from the queue and immediately deletes it.

trans-unit.source: This is simple, but if the receiver crashes before it finishes processing the message, the message will be lost.
trans-unit.target: This is simple, but if the receiver crashes before it finishes processing the message, the message will be lost.

trans-unit.source: Because it's been removed from the queue, no other receiver can access it.
trans-unit.target: Because it's been removed from the queue, no other receiver can access it.

trans-unit.source: The second option, *PeekLock*, is meant to help with this problem.
trans-unit.target: The second option, *PeekLock*, is meant to help with this problem.

trans-unit.source: Like ReceiveAndDelete, a PeekLock read removes a message from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Like ReceiveAndDelete, a PeekLock read removes a message from the queue.

trans-unit.source: It doesn't delete the message, however.
trans-unit.target: It doesn't delete the message, however.

trans-unit.source: Instead, it locks the message, making it invisible to other receivers, then waits for one of three events:
trans-unit.target: Instead, it locks the message, making it invisible to other receivers, then waits for one of three events:

trans-unit.source: If the receiver processes the message successfully, it calls *Complete*, and the queue deletes the message.
trans-unit.target: If the receiver processes the message successfully, it calls *Complete*, and the queue deletes the message.

trans-unit.source: If the receiver decides that it can't process the message successfully, it calls *Abandon*.
trans-unit.target: If the receiver decides that it can't process the message successfully, it calls *Abandon*.

trans-unit.source: The queue then removes the lock from the message and makes it available to other receivers.
trans-unit.target: The queue then removes the lock from the message and makes it available to other receivers.

trans-unit.source: If the receiver calls neither of these within a configurable period of time (by default, 60 seconds), the queue assumes the receiver has failed.
trans-unit.target: If the receiver calls neither of these within a configurable period of time (by default, 60 seconds), the queue assumes the receiver has failed.

trans-unit.source: In this case, it behaves as if the receiver had called Abandon, making the message available to other receivers.
trans-unit.target: In this case, it behaves as if the receiver had called Abandon, making the message available to other receivers.

trans-unit.source: Notice what can happen here: The same message might be delivered twice, perhaps to two different receivers.
trans-unit.target: Notice what can happen here: The same message might be delivered twice, perhaps to two different receivers.

trans-unit.source: Applications using Service Bus queues must be prepared for this.
trans-unit.target: Applications using Service Bus queues must be prepared for this.

trans-unit.source: To make duplicate detection easier, each message has a unique MessageID property that by default stays the same no matter how many times the message is read from a queue.
trans-unit.target: To make duplicate detection easier, each message has a unique MessageID property that by default stays the same no matter how many times the message is read from a queue.

trans-unit.source: Queues are useful in quite a few situations.
trans-unit.target: Queues are useful in quite a few situations.

trans-unit.source: They let applications communicate even when both aren't running at the same time, something that's especially handy with batch and mobile applications.
trans-unit.target: They let applications communicate even when both aren't running at the same time, something that's especially handy with batch and mobile applications.

trans-unit.source: A queue with multiple receivers also provides automatic load balancing, since sent messages are spread across these receivers.
trans-unit.target: A queue with multiple receivers also provides automatic load balancing, since sent messages are spread across these receivers.

trans-unit.source: Topics
trans-unit.target: Topics

trans-unit.source: Useful as they are, queues aren't always the right solution.
trans-unit.target: Useful as they are, queues aren't always the right solution.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, Service Bus topics are better.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, Service Bus topics are better.

trans-unit.source: Figure 3 illustrates this idea.
trans-unit.target: Figure 3 illustrates this idea.

trans-unit.source: Figure 3: Based on the filter a subscribing application specifies, it can receive some or all of the messages sent to a Service Bus topic.
trans-unit.target: Figure 3: Based on the filter a subscribing application specifies, it can receive some or all of the messages sent to a Service Bus topic.

trans-unit.source: A topic is similar in many ways to a queue.
trans-unit.target: A topic is similar in many ways to a queue.

trans-unit.source: Senders submit messages to a topic in the same way that they submit messages to a queue, and those messages look the same as with queues.
trans-unit.target: Senders submit messages to a topic in the same way that they submit messages to a queue, and those messages look the same as with queues.

trans-unit.source: The big difference is that topics let each receiving application create its own subscription by defining a *filter*.
trans-unit.target: The big difference is that topics let each receiving application create its own subscription by defining a *filter*.

trans-unit.source: A subscriber will then see only the messages that match that filter.
trans-unit.target: A subscriber will then see only the messages that match that filter.

trans-unit.source: For example, Figure 3 shows a sender and a topic with three subscribers, each with its own filter:
trans-unit.target: For example, Figure 3 shows a sender and a topic with three subscribers, each with its own filter:

trans-unit.source: Subscriber 1 receives only messages that contain the property *Seller="Ava"*.
trans-unit.target: Subscriber 1 receives only messages that contain the property *Seller="Ava"*.

trans-unit.source: Subscriber 2 receives messages that contain the property *Seller="Ruby"* and/or contain an *Amount* property whose value is greater than 100,000.
trans-unit.target: Subscriber 2 receives messages that contain the property *Seller="Ruby"* and/or contain an *Amount* property whose value is greater than 100,000.

trans-unit.source: Perhaps Ruby is the sales manager, and so she wants to see both her own sales and all big sales regardless of who makes them.
trans-unit.target: Perhaps Ruby is the sales manager, and so she wants to see both her own sales and all big sales regardless of who makes them.

trans-unit.source: Subscriber 3 has set its filter to *True*, which means that it receives all messages.
trans-unit.target: Subscriber 3 has set its filter to *True*, which means that it receives all messages.

trans-unit.source: For example, this application might be responsible for maintaining an audit trail and therefore it needs to see all the messages.
trans-unit.target: For example, this application might be responsible for maintaining an audit trail and therefore it needs to see all the messages.

trans-unit.source: As with queues, subscribers to a topic can read messages using either ReceiveAndDelete or PeekLock.
trans-unit.target: As with queues, subscribers to a topic can read messages using either ReceiveAndDelete or PeekLock.

trans-unit.source: Unlike queues, however, a single message sent to a topic can be received by multiple subscribers.
trans-unit.target: Unlike queues, however, a single message sent to a topic can be received by multiple subscribers.

trans-unit.source: This approach, commonly called *publish and subscribe*, is useful whenever multiple applications might be interested in the same messages.
trans-unit.target: This approach, commonly called *publish and subscribe*, is useful whenever multiple applications might be interested in the same messages.

trans-unit.source: By defining the right filter, each subscriber can tap into just the part of the message stream that it needs to see.
trans-unit.target: By defining the right filter, each subscriber can tap into just the part of the message stream that it needs to see.

trans-unit.source: Relays
trans-unit.target: Relays

trans-unit.source: Both queues and topics provide one-way asynchronous communication through a broker.
trans-unit.target: Both queues and topics provide one-way asynchronous communication through a broker.

trans-unit.source: Traffic flows in just one direction, and there's no direct connection between senders and receivers.
trans-unit.target: Traffic flows in just one direction, and there's no direct connection between senders and receivers.

trans-unit.source: But what if you don't want this?
trans-unit.target: But what if you don't want this?

trans-unit.source: Suppose your applications need to both send and receive messages, or perhaps you want a direct link between them and you don't need a broker to store messages.
trans-unit.target: Suppose your applications need to both send and receive messages, or perhaps you want a direct link between them and you don't need a broker to store messages.

trans-unit.source: To address scenarios such as this, Service Bus provides relays, as Figure 4 shows.
trans-unit.target: To address scenarios such as this, Service Bus provides relays, as Figure 4 shows.

trans-unit.source: Figure 4: Service Bus relay provides synchronous, two-way communication between applications.
trans-unit.target: Figure 4: Service Bus relay provides synchronous, two-way communication between applications.

trans-unit.source: The obvious question to ask about relays is this: Why would I use one?
trans-unit.target: The obvious question to ask about relays is this: Why would I use one?

trans-unit.source: Even if I don't need queues, why make applications communicate via a cloud service rather than just interact directly?
trans-unit.target: Even if I don't need queues, why make applications communicate via a cloud service rather than just interact directly?

trans-unit.source: The answer is that talking directly can be harder than you might think.
trans-unit.target: The answer is that talking directly can be harder than you might think.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you want to connect two on-premises applications, both running inside corporate datacenters.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you want to connect two on-premises applications, both running inside corporate datacenters.

trans-unit.source: Each of these applications sits behind a firewall, and each datacenter probably uses network address translation (NAT).
trans-unit.target: Each of these applications sits behind a firewall, and each datacenter probably uses network address translation (NAT).

trans-unit.source: The firewall blocks incoming data on all but a few ports, and NAT implies that the machine each application is running on doesn't have a fixed IP address that you can reach directly from outside the datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The firewall blocks incoming data on all but a few ports, and NAT implies that the machine each application is running on doesn't have a fixed IP address that you can reach directly from outside the datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Without some extra help, connecting these applications over the public Internet is problematic.
trans-unit.target: Without some extra help, connecting these applications over the public Internet is problematic.

trans-unit.source: A Service Bus relay provides this help.
trans-unit.target: A Service Bus relay provides this help.

trans-unit.source: To communicate bi-directionally through a relay, each application establishes an outbound TCP connection with Service Bus, then keeps it open.
trans-unit.target: To communicate bi-directionally through a relay, each application establishes an outbound TCP connection with Service Bus, then keeps it open.

trans-unit.source: All communication between the two applications will travel over these connections.
trans-unit.target: All communication between the two applications will travel over these connections.

trans-unit.source: Because each connection was established from inside the datacenter, the firewall will allow incoming traffic to each application without opening new ports.
trans-unit.target: Because each connection was established from inside the datacenter, the firewall will allow incoming traffic to each application without opening new ports.

trans-unit.source: This approach also gets around the NAT problem, because each application has a consistent endpoint in the cloud throughout the communication.
trans-unit.target: This approach also gets around the NAT problem, because each application has a consistent endpoint in the cloud throughout the communication.

trans-unit.source: By exchanging data through the relay, the applications can avoid the problems that would otherwise make communication difficult.
trans-unit.target: By exchanging data through the relay, the applications can avoid the problems that would otherwise make communication difficult.

trans-unit.source: To use Service Bus relays, applications rely on Windows Communication Foundation (WCF).
trans-unit.target: To use Service Bus relays, applications rely on Windows Communication Foundation (WCF).

trans-unit.source: Service Bus provides WCF bindings that make it straightforward for Windows applications to interact via relays.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus provides WCF bindings that make it straightforward for Windows applications to interact via relays.

trans-unit.source: Applications that already use WCF can typically just specify one of these bindings, then talk to each other through a relay.
trans-unit.target: Applications that already use WCF can typically just specify one of these bindings, then talk to each other through a relay.

trans-unit.source: Unlike queues and topics, however, using relays from non-Windows applications, while possible, requires some programming effort; no standard libraries are provided.
trans-unit.target: Unlike queues and topics, however, using relays from non-Windows applications, while possible, requires some programming effort; no standard libraries are provided.

trans-unit.source: Unlike queues and topics, applications don't explicitly create relays.
trans-unit.target: Unlike queues and topics, applications don't explicitly create relays.

trans-unit.source: Instead, when an application that wishes to receive messages establishes a TCP connection with Service Bus, a relay is created automatically.
trans-unit.target: Instead, when an application that wishes to receive messages establishes a TCP connection with Service Bus, a relay is created automatically.

trans-unit.source: When the connection is dropped, the relay is deleted.
trans-unit.target: When the connection is dropped, the relay is deleted.

trans-unit.source: To let an application find the relay created by a specific listener, Service Bus provides a registry that enables applications to locate a specific relay by name.
trans-unit.target: To let an application find the relay created by a specific listener, Service Bus provides a registry that enables applications to locate a specific relay by name.

trans-unit.source: Relays are the right solution when you need direct communication between applications.
trans-unit.target: Relays are the right solution when you need direct communication between applications.

trans-unit.source: For example, consider an airline reservation system running in an on-premises datacenter that must be accessed from check-in kiosks, mobile devices, and other computers.
trans-unit.target: For example, consider an airline reservation system running in an on-premises datacenter that must be accessed from check-in kiosks, mobile devices, and other computers.

trans-unit.source: Applications running on all of these systems could rely on Service Bus relays in the cloud to communicate, wherever they might be running.
trans-unit.target: Applications running on all of these systems could rely on Service Bus relays in the cloud to communicate, wherever they might be running.

trans-unit.source: Event Hubs
trans-unit.target: Event Hubs

trans-unit.source: Event Hubs is a highly scalable ingestion system that can process millions of events per second, enabling your application to process and analyze the massive amounts of data produced by your connected devices and applications.
trans-unit.target: Event Hubs is a highly scalable ingestion system that can process millions of events per second, enabling your application to process and analyze the massive amounts of data produced by your connected devices and applications.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could use an Event Hub to collect live engine performance data from a fleet of cars.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could use an Event Hub to collect live engine performance data from a fleet of cars.

trans-unit.source: Once collected into Event Hubs, you can transform and store data using any real-time analytics provider or storage cluster.
trans-unit.target: Once collected into Event Hubs, you can transform and store data using any real-time analytics provider or storage cluster.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Event Hubs, see the [Event Hubs overview](../event-hubs-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Event Hubs, see the [Event Hubs overview](../event-hubs-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: Connecting applications has always been part of building complete solutions, and the range of scenarios that require applications and services to communicate with each other is set to increase as more applications and devices are connected to the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Connecting applications has always been part of building complete solutions, and the range of scenarios that require applications and services to communicate with each other is set to increase as more applications and devices are connected to the Internet.

trans-unit.source: By providing cloud-based technologies for achieving this through queues, topics, relays, and Event Hubs, Service Bus aims to make this essential function easier to implement and more broadly available.
trans-unit.target: By providing cloud-based technologies for achieving this through queues, topics, relays, and Event Hubs, Service Bus aims to make this essential function easier to implement and more broadly available.
